pr_title: fix(iot-device): Fix issue where SDK didn't validate application properties correctly

timeline.message:
fix(iot-device): Fix issue where SDK didn't validate application properties correctly

Normally the SDK wouldn't validate something like this, but if a user tries to send an application property with an invalid character in it, the different protocols behave differently in unintuitive ways. MQTT will sever the connection with no error message while AMQPS and HTTPS will allow it.

I'm also taking this opportunity to fix a hack tied to URL encoding. URLEncoder doesn't handle encoding spaces correctly, but URIUtil from apache commons does

timeline.bodyText: URIUtil encodePath handles spaces correctly for our purposes, whereas URLEncoder did not, hence the switch
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: We weren't encoding the application property keys, which could be an issue. If a customer gives us a key with odd characters in it, we need to encode in order to keep the mqtt topic string valid
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Is this a final set of characters? where did you get them from? is it defined somewhere? can we have a link as a comment?
timeline.author: azabbasi

replies.bodyText: I got this requirement from our own documentation here: https://azure.github.io/azure-iot-sdk-java/device/com/microsoft/azure/iothub/MessageProperty.html
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: These tests were incorrect, as '/' characters are not allowed in application properties
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -46,32 +46,6 @@ public void constructorSavesPropertyValue()
 		
     }
 
-	 @Test
-    public void constructorSavesPropertyValueSlash()

timeline.bodyText: Same here. Tab is an illegal character, so we shouldn't have had a test like this
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: The userId wasn't being mocked properly, and it was hitting the codepath in MessageProperty.java that complains about the contents of the userId not being valid. Without this change, it was using a memory address with several illegal characters
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: This test was bad because these characters should never appear in an application property
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft
barustum

replies.bodyText: Yes, we need to use the URIUtil to encode some strings in this class
replies.author: timtay-microsoft
